document.title: Bayesian inference for the Brown–Resnick process, with an application to extreme low temperatures

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: Models for spatial extremes must account appropriately for asymptotic dependence, and this motivates the use of max-stable processes, which are the only non-trivial limits of properly rescaled pointwise maxima of random functions. The Brown–Resnick max-stable process has proven to be well-suited for modeling extremes of complex environmental processes, but in many applications its likelihood function is unobtainable and inference must be based on a composite likelihood, thereby preventing the use of classical Bayesian techniques. In this paper we exploit a case in which the full likelihood of a Brown–Resnick process can be calculated, using componentwise maxima and their partitions in terms of individual events, and we propose two new approaches to inference. The first estimates the partition using declustering, while the second uses the partition in a Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. We use these approaches to construct a Bayesian hierarchical max-stable model that can model complex spatial patterns in the marginal distributions of extremes and can describe their joint extremal dependence appropriately. We use this to model extreme low temperatures in northern Fennoscandia, in order to consider the likely effects of climate change on the risk of forest damage caused by outbreaks of pest insect populations.
Keywords: Forest ecology; Likelihood-based inference; Max-stable process; Non-stationary extremes; Partition; Space-time declustering

para.p: 1]EmericThibaudCorrespondingauthor.Email:emeric.thibaud@colostate.edu2]JuhaAalto1]DanielS.Cooley3]AnthonyC.Davison4]JuhaHeikkinen\affil[1]ColoradoStateUniversity,FortCollins,CO80523,U.S.A.\affil[2]FinnishMeteorologicalInstitute,00101Helsinki,Finland\affil[3]EcolePolytechniqueFédéraledeLausanne,1015Lausanne,Switzerland\affil[4]NaturalResourcesInstituteFinland,01370Vantaa,Finland

Extreme events such as heat or cold waves have major impacts on human health and ecological sustainability. Motivated by the pressing need for better risk assessment, inference for spatial extremes has developed rapidly during the last decade (e.g., 15; 51; 13; 32). de Haan (22) showed that max-stable processes are the only possible non-degenerate limits for rescaled pointwise maxima of random processes, thus motivating their use in modeling spatial extremes. Max-stable processes can describe extremal dependence, whereas the rarest extremes of Gaussian processes become essentially independent, leading to potential underestimation of the risks of the most severe events.

Flexible max-stable models have been developed for inference on spatial extremes. Over a variety of applications, the Brown–Resnick (5; 26) process has proven to be a valuable model for extremes of environmental processes, such as rainfall, temperature, wind speed and river discharge (see, e.g., 13; 19; 3; 6). This process is built using Gaussian processes and its dependence structure is determined by a variogram, so well-established ideas from classical geostatistics may be exported to the extremal context. The greater challenge is inference, since the full likelihood of the Brown–Resnick process is tractable only in relatively low-dimensional settings (23; 8). Composite likelihood techniques have been successfully used to fit max-stable models to block maxima or threshold exceedances, but with reduced estimation efficiency. More efficient procedures based on full (and possibly censored) likelihoods using Poisson or Pareto processes (19; 47; 44) have been developed for threshold exceedances, allowing the construction of more elaborate models for spatial extremes.

Bayesian hierarchical models are appealing in spatial statistics because of the flexibility with which they can model how marginal distributions vary over space. Casson & Coles (7), Cooley et al. (11) and Sang & Gelfand (35) constructed hierarchical models for extremes assuming conditional independence of extreme occurrences. Such models may have flexible marginal models but cannot produce realistic simulations of extreme events (51). Sang & Gelfand (36) and Fuentes et al. (20) used hierarchical models that model spatial dependence using Gaussian processes, but their proposals are asymptotically independent and thus cannot fully describe the dependence at the most extreme levels. Ribatet et al. (33) and Shaby (38) proposed the use of composite likelihoods in Monte Carlo algorithms and applied them for Bayesian inference on max-stable models, but these methods present computational challenges and are somewhat unsatisfactory. Shaby & Reich (39) constructed a hierarchical max-stable spatial model for extreme temperatures based on a hierarchical representation of logistic extreme-value distributions (42). Although their model has proven to be useful, it is hard to fit and its parameters are difficult to interpret.

In this paper we propose a flexible and readily interpretable Bayesian hierarchical model based on the Brown–Resnick process, which exploits a special case for which the full likelihood of such a process can be calculated, using the joint distribution of componentwise maxima and their partition in terms of individual events (41). We discuss the difficulties of using the partition in practice, and we propose a new Bayesian approach to fitting max-stable processes without estimating it.

Our method is motivated through modeling of extreme temperatures in northern Fennoscandia. In northern regions of Norway, Finland, Russia and Sweden, extreme low winter temperatures play a central role in ecological sustainability by limiting the extent of outbreaks of forest pests. This is the case for the autumnal moth Epirrita autumnata, whose larvae have caused serious forest damage by defoliating mountain birch. In northern Fennoscandia, forests have been mostly protected from this pest by extreme low temperatures, since its eggs cannot survive below -36∘C (45). Annual minimum temperatures are often below this threshold in the region, but in recent years they have increased. Although temperature is not the only factor limiting the spread of the moth, it is one of the most important, and thus plays a central role in the ecology of northern Fennoscandia. One of the most striking consequences of global change is likely increases in mean temperatures, especially for Arctic regions (43, §E.1). Changes in extremes have been studied less, but are projected to be greater in some regions, and may have huge consequences. In §4.4 we discuss the possible changes in annual minimum temperatures in northern Fennoscandia, focussing on the probability that they will be less than -36∘C.

Space-time models for temperatures are not new in the statistical literature. However, most existing approaches are based on the Gaussian distribution and thus may be inappropriate for extremes. Motivated by recent disastrous heat wave events over the world, max-stable processes and related methods have been used to model temperature extremes and their potential changes in time. Davison & Gholamrezaee (12) used the so-called Schlather (37) process to model annual maximum temperatures in Switzerland. They used latitude, longitude and elevation to estimate response surfaces for the marginal parameters of extremes. Their model seems appropriate for most of Switzerland but is too inflexible to model the variability of the marginal distributions over the complex terrain of the entire country. More complex models would be preferable but are difficult to fit using their framework. Fuentes et al. (20) describe a spatial model for annual maximum temperatures in the US based on mixtures of Gaussian distributions, and add flexibility by including random effects in the marginal parameters. Shaby & Reich (39) used a Bayesian max-stable model based on α-stable distributions to model extreme temperature data over Europe, with a similar use of random effects.

Section 2 describes the data we study. Section 3 summarises some extreme value ideas, and introduces the Brown–Resnick model and related inference methods. The hierarchical model, the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm and the application are discussed in Section 4.

We use temperature data from 20 meteorological stations located in northern regions of Finland, Norway and Sweden; see Fig. 1. The smallest and largest distances between two stations are 26 and 471 km. Daily minimum temperatures are available from 1960 to 2013, but with data missing. We focus on modeling minimum temperatures in the months December–March and we use the daily data to investigate their co-occurrences. Winter minimum values for the 20 stations are shown in Fig. 2.

Missing daily data censor the winter minima. In some periods there was no attempt to record data at some stations, but daily values are also missing even when they should have been recorded. To avoid missing too many minima, a procedure based on space-time filtering was used to judge if a missing datum could have been a winter minimum and whether or not it is effectively censored: if sample minima occurred within two days at multiple stations in a radius of 200 km, it is likely that this value reflects true atmospheric conditions, and that the minimum is not censored, thus we retained it, otherwise it was deleted. With this procedure, our dataset has at least 26 winter minima for each station and at least 15 observations for each year.

figure.toccaption: 1Locations of the 20 weather stations in the northern regions of Finland, Norway and Sweden. The dashed lines shows the convex hull of the stations which will be our region of interest for simulation.
figure.caption: Fig. 1Locations of the 20 weather stations in the northern regions of Finland, Norway and Sweden. The dashed lines shows the convex hull of the stations which will be our region of interest for simulation.

figure.toccaption: 2Winter minimum temperature (∘C) at the 20 stations (a different color for each station). Horizontal line is the -36∘C threshold.
figure.caption: Fig. 2Winter minimum temperature (∘C) at the 20 stations (a different color for each station). Horizontal line is the -36∘C threshold.

para.p: We derived covariates that are known to influence minimum temperature in northern Fennoscandia (1) and which were used for extrapolation. In addition to the coordinates of the stations, we use their absolute elevation above sea level and elevation relative to the surrounding areas (calculated on a 2 km × 2 km moving average), a proximity index to the Arctic Ocean, calculated with a 160 km × 160 km moving window assuming that the effect of the ocean reaches 80 km inland, and a lake cover index, calculated using a moving average with 3 km × 3 km moving window (details are given in 1).

The daily data show two types of dependence. At each location the temperatures are temporally dependent (see §2.3) due to temperature waves covering the stations for a few days. Within the region, the winter minima are spatially dependent because of the extent of such cold waves (see §2.4). These two aspects are critical to obtaining good estimates of return levels for extreme low temperatures, and must be taken into account in the construction of the model.

Daily minimum temperatures vary over the year, which complicates the analysis of daily extremes using a peaks-over-threshold approach, because the threshold must also vary seasonally. Extremal analysis is easier using a block approach, and we model the winter minima only, taking the data to be stationary over the months December–March, as seems reasonable. It is difficult to detect the presence of a temporal trend with only 53 years of noisy data, but Fig. 2 suggests that minima may generally be slightly less extreme from 1990 onwards. The inclusion of a temporal effect to the model will help to assess this.

Temperatures, and in particular daily minimum temperatures, tend to be very dependent from day to day, since cold waves stay over a region for a few days. Preliminary analysis (see Supporting Information) showed that the dependence is strong for the first few days and vanishes after approximately five to ten days at each location.

In view of our application, inference is needed only for the winter minima. Temporal dependence is not of interest in itself, but it represents a difficulty for inference, as the daily data cannot be considered to be independent. One way to account for temporal dependence would be to use a space-time model for extremes, as in Huser & Davison (24) and Buhl & Klüppelberg (6), but fitting such models is very complicated, and since the temporal dependence is not of interest in our application, it seems unnecessary to model it explicitly. Thus, we consider modeling the winter minima, which usually correspond to annual minima. We will consider an approach that requires us to partition winter minima in terms of independent generating events, which is complicated by the presence of temporal dependence; see §4.2.3.

We expect winter minimum temperatures to be dependent over large regions, and this seems to be the case in our data. Fig. 2 suggests that the minima for the 20 stations behave similarly for the 53 years: the years 1966 and 1999 were very cold at all 20 locations, whereas 1973, 1993 and 2007 correspond to warmer years at all locations. It appears that most of the minima occurred on the same day or only a few days apart, so they may correspond to the same event, which suggests strong spatial dependence.

Asymptotic independence is a degenerate case for which max-stable models are unsuitable. Although the serial dependence and the relatively short time series make assessment challenging, exploratory analysis indicates that the minima appear to be asymptotically dependent (see Supporting Information).

section.title: 3Max-stable processes and inference for spatial extremes

para.p: Let =Y{⁢Y(s)}∈sS be a random process with continuous sample paths defined over a compact subset S of \Realm, and let Y1,Y2,… be independent replicates of Y. If there exist sequences of continuous functions >{⁢an(s)}∈sS0 and {⁢bn(s)}∈sS such that we have the distributional convergence

Math.text: formulae@((set@(a _ n * s ^ (- 1) * delimited-[]@(maximum@(Y _ 1 * s, ldots, Y _ n * s) - b _ n * s))) _ (s element-of S) rightarrow (set@(Z * s)) _ (s element-of S), n rightarrow infinity)

para.p: where =Z{⁢Z(s)}∈sS is a non-degenerate random process, we say that Y lies in the max-domain of attraction of the process Z. Then the process Z must be max-stable (15) and its marginals are of generalized extreme-value (GEV) form,

denoted ∼⁢Z(s)⁢GEV{⁢μ(s),⁢σ(s),⁢ξ(s)}, with =x+max(0,x), and real location ⁢μ(s), scale >⁢σ(s)0 and shape ⁢ξ(s) parameters; the case =⁢ξ(s)0 is defined as the limit for →⁢ξ(s)0 throughout the paper. Every max-stable process with marginal parameters ⁢μ(s), ⁢σ(s) and ⁢ξ(s) can be written as +⁢μ(s)⁢σ(s)ξ(s)-1{-⁢Z(s)⁢ξ(s)1} where Z is a simple max-stable process with unit Fréchet margins, i.e., ⁢μ(s)=⁢σ(s)=⁢ξ(s)=1. Thus it suffices to focus on simple max-stable processes, henceforth denoted by Z.
As a consequence of max-stability, for every set of locations ∈s1,…,sDS,
where the so-called exponent function V is homogeneous of order -1, i.e., =⁢V(⁢tz1,…,⁢tzD)⁢t-1V(z1,…,zD), >t0, and satisfies =⁢V(∞,…,∞,z,∞,…,∞)z-1. In particular,

where θ=⁢V(1,…,1)∈[1,D] is known as the extremal coefficient of Z relative to s1,…,sD. The extremal coefficient can be interpreted as the number of independent variables among ⁢Z(s1),…,⁢Z(sD) and is useful for model checking, since it can be estimated non-parametrically.

As they appear as the only possible non-degenerate limits for rescaled pointwise maxima of random processes, max-stable processes are natural models for observed block maxima. Moreover, the equality =min{⁢Y1(s),…,⁢Yn(s)}-max{-⁢Y1(s),…,-⁢Yn(s)} shows that such processes are also natural models for block minima.

Several parametric max-stable models have been proposed. The Smith (40) process was the first to be considered but its realizations are too smooth for realistic modeling of complex extremes. The Schlather (37) process is constructed from stationary Gaussian processes and provides more realistic realizations controlled by different correlation functions. The extremal-t process extends the Schlather process by introducing an additional shape parameter (29). Here we focus on the Brown–Resnick process (5; 26), which can be seen as a limiting case of extremal-t processes, and appears to be a good model for extremes of environmental processes.
Kabluchko et al. (26) constructed a stationary max-stable process, called the Brown–Resnick process, as

Math.text: formulae@(Z * s = (maximum _ (i = list@(1, 2, ldots)))@((Q _ i) ^ (- 1) * W _ i) * s, formulae@(W _ i * s = exponential@(varepsilon _ i * s - (sigma * s ^ 2) / 2), s element-of S))

para.p: where the Qi’s are the points of a unit rate Poisson process on (0,∞) and the εi are independent replicates of an intrinsically stationary centered Gaussian process ε with variance ⁢σ(s)2. The dependence structure of Z is inherited from that of ε, which is controlled by the variogram =⁢2γ(h)⁢E[{-⁢ε(+sh)⁢ε(s)}2]. Without loss of generality, we let =⁢ε(0)0, so =⁢σ(s)2⁢2γ(s). A large class of models is attainable through the choice of different variograms. Later we use the stable variogram =⁢2γ(h)⁢2(/∥h∥λ)κ, with >λ0 and ∈κ(0,2]. Dieker & Mikosch (52) found a representation equivalent to (3) that enables exact simulation of Brown–Resnick processes at a finite set of locations.
The exponent function of a Brown–Resnick process is (28)

Math.text: V * vector@(z _ 1, ldots, z _ D) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ D)@((z _ j) ^ (- 1) * Phi _ (D - 1) * list@(logarithm@(z _ (- j) / z _ j), Gamma _ (list@(- j, j)), (Gamma _ (list@(- j, j)) * (1 _ (D - 1)) ^ prime + Gamma _ (list@(j, - j)) * 1 _ (D - 1)) - Gamma _ (list@(- j, - j))))

para.p: where ⁢Φp(⋅;μ,Ω) is the cumulative distribution function of a p-dimensional Gaussian distribution with mean vector μ and covariance matrix Ω, 1-D1=(1,…,1)′∈\Real-D1, =Γ{⁢γ(-sj1sj2)}≤1j1,≤j2D, Γ-j,j denotes the ×(-D1)1 vector consisting of the jth column of Γ without its jth component, Γ-j,-j denotes the matrix Γ without its jth row and jth column, and so forth.
Differentiation of (2) shows that the full likelihood of a max-stable process may be written as

Math.text: (sum _ (Pi = vector@(pi _ 1, ldots, pi _ K) element-of P))@(((product _ (k = 1)) ^ K)@(set@(- V _ pi _ k * vector@(Z _ 1, ldots, Z _ D)) * exponential@(- V * vector@(Z _ 1, ldots, Z _ D))))

para.p: where P denotes the set of all partitions of {1,…,D} and the subscript πk on Vπk denotes the partial derivative of the function V with respect to the components in the subset πk. Although the likelihood has a closed form expression for the Brown–Resnick process (47), the size of P equals the Bell number and is larger than 105 for ≥D10, making full likelihood inference computationally unattainable in many situations. Hence inference for max-stable processes has typically been based on composite likelihoods using lower-order densities (30; 23; 8). Not only do composite likelihoods result in a loss of efficiency compared to full likelihood estimation, they also increase the computational burden when employed in a Bayesian analysis as the composite likelihood does not directly yield a posterior which accurately accounts for parameter uncertainty (33; 38). Engelke et al. (19), Wadsworth & Tawn (47) and Thibaud & Opitz (44) developed full likelihood inference for threshold exceedances of processes in the max-domain of attraction of a Brown–Resnick process, which, while still computationally challenging, have less computational burden than that required by (5).
For our likelihood, we employ the result of Wadsworth & Tawn (47) who showed that, for the Brown–Resnick process, partial derivatives of V with respect to the first d indices, denoted V:1d, equal

Math.text: - _ V * z = ((Phi _ (D - d) * list@(logarithm@(z _ (d + 1 colon D)), tilde@(tau), tilde@(Gamma))) / ((2 * pi) ^ ((d - 1) / 2) * (absolute-value@(Sigma _ (1 colon d))) ^ (1 / 2) * ((1 _ d) ^ prime * q _ d) ^ (1 / 2) * ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ d)@(z _ j))) * exponential@(- (1 / 2) * ((((1 / 4) * ^ (_ sigma) * ^ (_ Sigma) * _ sigma - (1 / 4) * (((sigma _ d) ^ prime * q _ d * (q _ d) ^ prime * sigma _ d) / ((1 _ d) ^ prime * q _ d))) + ((sigma _ d) ^ prime * q _ d) / ((1 _ d) ^ prime * q _ d)) - 1 / ((1 _ d) ^ prime * q _ d))) * exponential@(- (1 / 2) * set@((logarithm@(^ (_ z) * _ A * logarithm@(_ z)) + logarithm@(^ (_ z)) * ((2 * q _ d) / ((1 _ d) ^ prime * q _ d)) + ^ (_ Sigma) * _ sigma) - (q _ d * (q _ d) ^ prime * sigma _ d) / ((1 _ d) ^ prime * q _ d)))

para.p: with =Σ{-+⁢γ(sj1)⁢γ(sj2)⁢γ(-sj1sj2)}≤1j1,≤j2D, =σ⁢diag(Σ), =qd⁢Σ:1d-11d, =A-Σ-1⁢/⁢qq′1D′q, =σdσ:1d, and

Math.text: formulae@(tilde@(Gamma) = ((K _ 01) ^ prime * A * K _ 01) ^ (- 1), tilde@(tau) = - tilde@(Gamma) * ((K _ 01) ^ prime * A * K _ 01 * logarithm@(z _ (1 colon d)) + (((K _ 01) ^ prime * Sigma ^ (- 1) * 1 _ D) / (1 _ D) ^ prime) * Sigma ^ (- 1) * 1 _ D))

para.p: where

Math.text: formulae@(K _ 10 = Array[[I _ d], [0 _ (list@(D - d, d))]], K _ 01 = Array[[0 _ (list@(d, D - d))], [I _ (d - d)]])

para.p: Stephenson & Tawn (41) derived a likelihood based on componentwise block maxima and their occurrence times that avoids direct differentiation of (2). Let Y1,Y2,… denote independent replicates of a random vector Y={⁢Y(s1),…,⁢Y(sD)}∈\RealD. Without loss of generality, suppose that the process Y has unit Fréchet margins and lies in the max-domain of attraction of a simple max-stable process Z. Let =Mnmax=i1,…,n/Yin, and let =Πn(π1,…,πK) denote the unique partition of {1,…,D} such that {Mn,j}∈jπk comes from the same individual observation, i.e., for each 1≤k≤K, there exists ik such that ={Mn,j}∈jπk{/Yik,jn}∈jπk. Then Stephenson & Tawn (41) showed that, as →n∞, the block maximum and its associated partition (Mn,Πn) converge in distribution to (Z,Π), whose joint density is

Math.text: f * open-interval@(Z, Pi) = exponential@(- V * Z) * (product _ (pi _ k element-of Pi))@(set@(- V _ pi _ k * Z))

para.p: This suggests using (7) as a likelihood for inference on the joint distribution of block maxima and their occurrence times. The contributions for each block are multiplied to form the full likelihood function for N independent replicates of block maxima.

The Stephenson–Tawn approach can be seen as a special case of the point process approach of Wadsworth & Tawn (47), who used the convergence of the point process of {/Yin:=i1,…,n} to a Poisson process with intensity -⁢V:1D(y) to propose a censored likelihood to fit the Poisson model to the exceedances of Yi above high marginal thresholds. By fixing the marginal thresholds at the observed maxima Z, the censored likelihood equals (7).

This approach only requires the maximum and the partition to be observed, and thus represents a compromise between the block maximum and threshold exceedance approaches. The relative efficiency of the Stephenson–Tawn and the pairwise maximum likelihood estimators has been investigated by Wadsworth & Tawn (47). Because the partition contains information about the dependence, the variance of the Stephenson–Tawn estimator is lower than that of the corresponding estimator based only on the block maxima. However, for finite block length, the former may be more biased, because the model (Z,Π) is misspecified for (Mn,Πn), i.e., both for the maxima and the partition (46). Use of the limiting distribution for (Mn,Πn) represents a strong assumption that can lead to poor fit, whereas approaches based on the maximum Mn alone are more robust.

A further difficulty arises from the definition of the partition for serially dependent data. The partition in the Stephenson–Tawn model is defined in terms of independent generating events. While it is natural to define the partition in terms of the days of occurrence of the maxima when the daily observations are independent, its estimation is harder when data show temporal dependence. In §4.2.3 we propose a space-time declustering procedure to estimate the partition.

Although the use of the partition is theoretically appealing it represents a practical challenge. First, the model is misspecified, which affects the estimation of the max-stable model by the introduction of biased information. Second, the partition must be estimated in a preliminary step, and inference based on the Stephenson–Tawn model is conditional on the fixed partition and ignores the uncertainty associated to its estimation. The partition is not always very well defined (see §4.2.3) and its estimation is sensitive to measurement error. This motivates us to propose an approach to estimating the parameters of the Brown–Resnick process without using the partition. The partition-free model we introduce here uses only the values of the maxima and can be used when the dates of occurrence are unavailable.

Let =Z{⁢Z(s1),…,⁢Z(sD)} be a vector stemming from a Brown–Resnick process Z. To overcome the intractability of the likelihood (5), we propose to augment the data with the unknown partition Π that generates Z in terms of the functions =Pi⁢Qi-1Wi(s) in (3), i.e., =Π(π1,…,πK) is defined such that the points ⁢Z(sj) in the same set πk come from the same functions Pi. The joint distribution of (Z,Π) is (7).

We impute the unknown partition Π given the observed value of Z in an MCMC algorithm, using ideas similar to Dombry et al. (17) who considered the partition in the context of conditional simulation from max-stable processes. The partition is imputed from its conditional distribution given the data. From (7) we have

Math.text: Pr@(Pi = pi, Z = z) = (f * open-interval@(z, pi)) / (sum _ (pi element-of P))@(f * open-interval@(z, pi))

para.p: However, the number of partitions of the set {1,…,D} is the D-th Bell number, so that (8) is intractable for large D, so we use the Gibbs sampler proposed by Dombry et al. (17) to update the partition. For a partition =π(π1,…,πK), we choose a location sj at random and let π-j denote the restriction of π to ∖{s1,…,sD}{sj}. The size of π-j is K, or (-K1) if {sj} is itself a cluster of π. Given π-j, the cluster of sj is updated by attributing this location either to an existing cluster of π-j or to a new cluster, giving at most +K1 choices. The conditional probability for a new partition π* with =π*-jπ-j is

Math.text: Pr@(Pi = pi ^ *, Pi _ (- j) = pi _ (- j), Z = z) = (f * open-interval@(z, pi ^ *)) / (sum _ (tilde@(pi) element-of P colon (tilde@(pi)) _ (- j) = pi _ (- j)))@(f * open-interval@(z, tilde@(pi)))

para.p: The discrete distribution (9) has support on a space of dimension at most +K1, so a new partition π* can easily be simulated.

In practice, inference is based on independent replicates Z1,…,ZN, and the MCMC algorithm independently updates the corresponding latent partitions Π1,…,ΠN. Given the observed values for the Zi and the simulated Πi, the marginal and dependence parameters of the model are updated from the joint distribution of the (Zi,Πi), which is a product of terms of the form (7).

section.title: 4Modeling extreme low temperatures in northern Fennoscandia

para.p: We first fitted GEV distributions at each of the 20 stations independently. The estimates for the scale and shape parameters were not significantly different from site to site, but variation in the location parameter estimates suggested use of a non-stationary GEV model with spatially varying location parameter but constant scale and shape parameters.

We then fitted non-stationary marginal models at the 20 locations by maximizing the independence likelihood, which assumes the independence of the temperatures from site to site. Non-stationarity was modeled using trend surfaces defined from the covariates mentioned in §2.1 and temporal trends in the location and scale parameters; we used the R package SpatialExtremes (34) to fit these models, which were compared using the Takeuchi information criterion. Our best model had six covariates for the location surface, constant scale and shape parameters, and a temporal trend in the location only. Its fit was assessed using marginal QQ-plots (see the Supporting Information): departure from the %95 confidence intervals was observed for five stations. This suggests that the trend surface model is not flexible enough to model the variability in the location parameters over the 20 stations. Inclusion of additional covariates did not help to improve the fit. These results motivate the use of a more complex approach that allows greater flexibility in modeling marginal distributions.

We consider two approaches to estimate the parameters of the Brown–Resnick model. The first uses the Stephenson–Tawn model and estimates the partition in a preliminary step through space-time declustering; see §§3.3, 4.2.3. The second imputes the partition in the MCMC algorithm via a data augmentation principle; see §3.4. In this section we describe the part of the hierarchical model for the data conditional on the partition which is common to both approaches.

Let =yi(y⁢i1,…,y⁢iD), =i1,…,N, denote the observed winter minima, s1,…,sD the =D20 locations of the stations such that =y⁢ij⁢yi(sj), ∈t⁢ij\Real the covariate for the day of occurrence of the winter minima y⁢ij, defined as the number of years from 1 January 2000, and finally let =πi(π⁢i1,…,π⁢iKi) denote the partitions of {1,…,D} for each year. When data are missing, the dimension of yi is lower than D and so too is the dimension of the corresponding partition. The first level of the hierarchical model gives the probability density of the observed minima, conditional on the marginal and dependence parameters ψ and the partitions π1,…,πN, as
where

denotes the marginal transformation to the standard Fréchet scale for ≠ξ⁢ij0 and the prime denotes derivative with respect to y; the negative signs for the y⁢ij’s in (10) correspond to modeling negated winter minima.

The second level of the hierarchical model specifies the models for the exponent measure V and the GEV parameters. We define a space-time model for μ with the covariates discussed in §2.1, with a linear temporal trend, and with a Gaussian prior distribution as

Math.text: mu * open-interval@(s, t) similar-to GP * set@(X * s * beta, tau ^ 2 * rho) + alpha * t

para.p: where ⁢X(s) denotes the vector of the intercept and covariates at location s, and ⁢GP{⁢x(s),⁢τ2ρ} denotes a Gaussian process with mean ⁢x(s), variance τ2, and correlation function =⁢ρ(h)exp(-/∥h∥δ). The random effect allows the location parameters to vary smoothly over space, in addition to any effect of the covariates. We kept σ and ξ constant over space and time for simplicity and because this appeared to suffice for a good fit. Thus =μ⁢ij⁢μ(sj,t⁢ij), =σ⁢ijσ, and =ξ⁢ijξ for each pair of replicate and location indices (i,j), and the marginal GEV distributions of the model at the observed data can be written as

Math.text: - y _ (i * j) similar-to GEV * vector@(W _ j + alpha _ mu * t _ (i * j), sigma, xi)

para.p: where =W(W1,…,WD) is a Gaussian vector with mean ⁢Xβ, where X is a ×D7 matrix with rows ⁢X(sj), and covariance matrix {⁢τ2ρ(-sj1sj2)}≤1j1,≤j2D. We use a Brown–Resnick process with variogram =⁢2γ(h)⁢2(/∥h∥λ)κ as a model for the exponent function V.

Prior distributions are assigned to the variables at the last level of a hierarchical model. We used vague priors for all parameters except those of the latent Gaussian field; see the Supporting Information. The prior distributions for β and τ2 were chosen to obtain conjugate full conditional distributions for these parameters, and Metropolis–Hasting steps were used to sample from those of the other parameters.

Previous work suggests that it can be difficult to estimate both the sill and range parameters of a Gaussian process (48), especially when this is used as a prior in a hierarchical model with few stations. To overcome identifiability issues, Davison et al. (51) used informative priors for these parameters. On the other hand, Cooley et al. (11) showed that although it is difficult to estimate each parameter individually, the estimation of their product tends to be more stable. These parameters are used for extrapolation through the conditional distribution of the Gaussian process, but their values are not of direct interest. In our application, we found that different priors for τ2 and δ can give quite different posterior densities but the effect of the priors on the extrapolated surface for the random effect in μ is small.

The use of the Stephenson–Tawn model requires one to identify the partition in (7) which must correspond to independent individual events. Several approaches have been proposed to identify clusters in univariate time series (e.g., 4, Chapter 10; 9). In the multivariate case, declustering techniques have been proposed by Coles & Tawn (10) and Nadarajah (27). Here we follow Coles & Tawn (10), who identified clusters of storm surges by assuming that events separated by a fixed time lag are independent.

In our application, a difficulty arises from the use of the dates of occurrences. Because of the measurement precision of the temperatures (0.1∘C), the dates of occurrence of the minima are not always unique, which affects the estimation of the partition; we use one date chosen at random.

For our temperature data, preliminary analysis suggests we choose a time lag of five days: two observations at the same location and separated by more than five days are assumed to be independent. To identify clusters for the 20 time series, we use a single linkage (or friend-to-friend) method whereby a cluster is composed of data that are dependent in pairs. Thus if the minima occurred at time 1 for the first series, time 4 for the second and time 7 for the third, these three minima are considered to lie in the same cluster. With this procedure, the number of clusters per year is at most five, and winter temperature minima usually occurred from widespread events that lasted between five and ten days.

The evaluation of the likelihood (10) for a Brown–Resnick process requires many evaluations of the exponent function V and its partial derivatives. Because the normal cumulative distribution function is involved in these functions, the likelihood (10) cannot be calculated exactly and an estimator must be used in the MCMC algorithm. We discuss here the effect of this on the MCMC algorithm.

Andrieu & Roberts (2) showed that if the estimator of the likelihood function used in the MCMC algorithm is unbiased then the resulting Markov chain admits the targeted posterior distribution as stationary distribution, though the variance of the likelihood estimator affects the mixing of the algorithm; if it is very large, the Markov chain mixes poorly. Doucet et al. (18) investigate the effects of the variance of the estimator of the log-likelihood on the MCMC algorithm. Their results suggest using an estimator with a standard deviation at most 1.2 to obtain a well-mixing Markov chain.

The likelihood (10) factorizes into products of terms exp{-⁢V(⋅)} and ⁢Vπ⁢ik(⋅), given respectively in (4) and (6). We estimated the cumulative normal distribution functions using a randomized quasi Monte Carlo algorithm with antithetic variables similar to that described in Genz & Bretz (21), §4.2.2. The resulting estimator is unbiased for the Gaussian distribution function, and thus provides an unbiased estimator for V and its partial derivatives. However, the plug-in estimator for the terms exp{-⁢V(⋅)} is biased. An unbiased estimator for these terms could be obtained by simulating from the Brown–Resnick process but unreported results showed that this is too slow to be used in our algorithm. There is a trade-off between the calculation time required for the unbiased estimator and the smaller variance of the biased estimator. Fortunately, the bias can be made arbitrarily small by increasing the number of simulations in the Monte Carlo algorithm, thereby mitigating the effect of the bias on the inference. Hence we need an estimator for V with a very small variance, while those of Vπk can have larger variances.

We tuned Ne, the number of simulations in the Monte Carlo approximations for the terms exp{-⁢V(⋅)}, and Nd, the number of simulations in the Monte Carlo approximations for the terms ⁢Vπ⁢ik(⋅), to achieve desirable variances for these two terms. We used simulation to investigate the effect of Ne and Nc on the estimator of the log-likelihood. For =Ne100, the standard error of the estimator of ∑=i1N⁢V{⁢f⁢i1(y⁢i1),…,⁢f⁢iD(y⁢iD)} is around 0.02, which should not bias the estimator of the likelihood too much. For =Nd25 the standard error of the log-likelihood estimator is around 0.2 and the calculation time is reasonable.

An evaluation of the likelihood (10) of the Brown–Resnick process for our dataset takes approximately one second, and it must be evaluated to update each of the marginal and dependence parameters. Moreover, when parameters are very dependent, the Gibbs sampler can mix slowly, so we updated the parameters in blocks. We chose to update the vector W of location parameters in one block using a multivariate normal proposal in a Metropolis–Hasting step. The covariance matrix of the proposal was adapted during a burn-in period. The parameters σ and λ were updated on a log scale because their distributions are typically asymmetric. Furthermore the parameters logσ, logλ and κ were found to be very dependent, so we updated them jointly using an adaptive Metropolis–Hasting step. The parameters α and ξ were updated individually. Four evaluations of the likelihood (10) are required to update the marginal and dependence parameters.

For the partition-free model of §3.4, the Gibbs sampler for the partition takes approximately one second per iteration of the MCMC algorithm. An additional evaluation of the likelihood (10) is necessary to update the likelihood value, which adds approximately two seconds to the MCMC algorithm for the fixed partition.

Since one iteration of the MCMC algorithm takes several seconds on a single CPU, we used parallel computing, fitting 50 independent Markov chains each of length 15,000 and discarding the first 5000 iterations of each chain. The resulting chains were merged to obtain a final chain of length 500,000. The diagnostics of the MCMC algorithm are discussed in the Supporting Information. The mean of the posterior distributions were used as point-wise estimators. Credible intervals were calculated from the quantiles of the Markov chains.

We performed a simple simulation study to assess the ability of the MCMC algorithm to provide accurate inference on the model parameters; see the Supporting Information. The results suggest the MCMC algorithm is able to provide sensible inferences: the posterior means were close to the true values and the empirical coverages of the credible intervals were close to the nominal values.

We compare results from three non-stationary Brown–Resnick models. The first (M1) uses the same trend surfaces as does the best marginal model discussed in §4.1 and is fitted using pairwise likelihood (30) as implemented in the R package SpatialExtremes; this is our baseline model, to which we compare our new approaches. The second (M2) is the Bayesian hierarchical model that uses the fixed partition from the declustering procedure. The third (M3) is the Bayesian hierarchical model without the partition. These three models have the same parameters except that we use all covariates for the location parameter in the two Bayesian models.

table.toccaption: 1Parameter estimates (mean of posterior distributions) and %95 confidence/credible intervals from the trend surface model (M1), the Bayesian model based on the declustering (M2), and the partition-free Bayesian model (M3). The second column is the estimate for the mean value of the location parameter =μj⁢μ(sj,0) over the 20 stations.
table.caption: Table 1Parameter estimates (mean of posterior distributions) and %95 confidence/credible intervals from the trend surface model (M1), the Bayesian model based on the declustering (M2), and the partition-free Bayesian model (M3). The second column is the estimate for the mean value of the location parameter =μj⁢μ(sj,0) over the 20 stations.

para.p: We discuss the estimates in terms of the negated location parameter μ, and negated trend α, which corresponds to the original scale of minimum temperatures. The estimates for the three models are given in Table 1. We assessed the fit of the marginal distributions using QQ-plots (see the Supporting Information). We assessed the fit of the dependence model in terms of empirical pairwise extremal coefficients, computed using the empirical marginal distributions of the data to avoid potential bias due to the estimation of the marginals (32); see Fig. 3. As a global assessment of the fit in terms of the marginals and dependence, we computed the maximum of winter minimum temperatures over four different sets of stations, for the 53 years of the dataset, and compared the observed values with the predictions from the three Brown–Resnick models; see Fig. 4. Further diagnostics for the prediction of the minimum and the averages of winter minimum temperatures are given in the Supporting Information.

figure.toccaption: 3Binned estimates of empirical pairwise extremal coefficients (black, with their %95 confidence intervals). Curves are from the fitted Brown–Resnick models (see Table 1): M1 in blue, M2 in green, and M3 in red.
figure.caption: Fig. 3Binned estimates of empirical pairwise extremal coefficients (black, with their %95 confidence intervals). Curves are from the fitted Brown–Resnick models (see Table 1): M1 in blue, M2 in green, and M3 in red.

figure.toccaption: 4Model checking for the three Brown–Resnick models (see Table 1): M1 (top row), M2 (middle row) and M3 (bottom row). The QQ-plots compare the predictions and the observed maximum of winter minimum temperatures (∘C) over some groups of stations, =mimax∈jJy⁢ij, =i1,…,53. The columns, from left to right, correspond to the group of stations =J{5,16,17,18,19} (western region), =J{2,3,4,6,7,8,9,12,20} (eastern region), =J{5,6,8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15,19,20} (northern region), and all 20 stations. Grey dashed lines are %95 confidence bands, and the solid grey line indicates a perfect fit.
figure.caption: Fig. 4Model checking for the three Brown–Resnick models (see Table 1): M1 (top row), M2 (middle row) and M3 (bottom row). The QQ-plots compare the predictions and the observed maximum of winter minimum temperatures (∘C) over some groups of stations, =mimax∈jJy⁢ij, =i1,…,53. The columns, from left to right, correspond to the group of stations =J{5,16,17,18,19} (western region), =J{2,3,4,6,7,8,9,12,20} (eastern region), =J{5,6,8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15,19,20} (northern region), and all 20 stations. Grey dashed lines are %95 confidence bands, and the solid grey line indicates a perfect fit.

para.p: For the trend surface model (M1), the marginal QQ-plots show poor fits for six stations. Moreover, the model severely underestimates the dependence in terms of the pairwise extremal coefficient. This can be explained by the inadequacy of the fitted marginal distributions, which bias the dependence estimates; Ribatet (32) also observed this when modeling wind gust data. In terms of predicting the maximum over groups of stations, the models performs poorly: many points lie outside the %95 confidence bounds. In general, this model does not provide good predictions of extreme temperatures.

For the Bayesian model based on the declustering (M2), the marginal QQ-plots show that the sample quantiles are outside the %95 confidence bands for three stations, and underestimate them systematically at all stations; the estimated scale parameter σ seems too large. The model overestimates the pairwise dependence somewhat, and tends to overestimate return levels for the maxima over different groups of stations.

For the Bayesian partition-free model (M3), the marginal QQ-plots show a good fit of the GEV distributions: the empirical quantiles are in the %95 confidence bands for all the stations. The constant scale and shape parameters model can provide good fits of the marginal distirbutions. The empirical pairwise extremal coefficients agree adequately with the curve from the model. In terms of the multivariate predictions, the model can produce better predictions for the maximum, minimum and average of the minima than does M2, with all the observations within the %95 confidence bounds; see Fig. 4 and the Supporting Information. This model appears to represent both the marginal and spatial behavior of extreme low temperatures adequately.

We further discuss the results for the partition-free Bayesian model (M3). Fig. 5(a) shows the posterior mean of the random effects for the location parameter over the convex hull of the meteorological stations (see Fig. 1), and the mean of the GEV distribution for the year 2016. We restrict our analysis to the convex hull of the stations because extrapolation too far from the stations is too uncertain. The posterior mean of the random effect in the location parameters shows the variability in this parameter that cannot be explained by the covariates. The posterior mean for the fitted GEV distributions shows lower temperatures in the inland region. The signs of the regression parameters for the trend surface in the location parameter are negative for latitude, longitude and relative elevation, and positive for distance to the Arctic Ocean, lake cover index and elevation. Similar covariate effects were found by Aalto et al. (1) for extreme low temperatures in northern Fennoscandia. The estimated shape parameter, corresponding to Weibull—so-called light-tailed—distributions, agrees with previous studies on extreme temperatures suggesting that the shape parameter should be negative. The dependence parameters correspond to long-range dependence, with pairwise extremal coefficient =^θ⁢1.42(1.34,1.50) at 400 km, while =^κ⁢0.53(0.43,0.64) implies that the realizations from the Brown–Resnick process are continuous but nowhere differentiable: the process shows small-scale variation.

figure.toccaption: 5Posterior mean of the random effect in the location parameter (a) and mean of the GEV distribution for the year 2016 (b). The scale corresponds to temperature minima (∘C).
figure.caption: Fig. 5Posterior mean of the random effect in the location parameter (a) and mean of the GEV distribution for the year 2016 (b). The scale corresponds to temperature minima (∘C).

para.p: We base our forecasts on the partition-free Bayesian model (M3). Changes in extremes are entirely based on the linear trend α in the location parameter. This translates to changes in the mean of the GEV distribution at location s and year t, which is

Math.text: formulae@(list@(mu * open-interval@(s, 0) + alpha * t + sigma * xi ^ (- 1) * set@(Gamma * (1 - xi) - 1), xi) less 1, xi not-equals 0.)

para.p: The estimate =-^α⁢0.06(0.01,0.11) corresponds to an increase of 0.6∘C per decade in the mean annual minimum temperature. Fig. 5(b) shows the predicted mean annual minimum temperature for 2016. Fig. 6 shows the probability that annual minimum temperatures are higher than -36∘C, the threshold needed for protecting northern Fennoscandia forests from outbreaks of Epirrita autumnata, for 1980, 2016 and 2030. There is a strong change in these probabilities. Over the region defined by the stations, the annual minimum temperatures had low probability of exceeding -36∘C before 1980, but this probability is about 0.55 for 2016, and rises to 0.62 for 2030 according to the fitted model.

figure.toccaption: 6Probability that the annual minimum temperature is higher than -36∘C for 1980, 2016 and 2030.
figure.caption: Fig. 6Probability that the annual minimum temperature is higher than -36∘C for 1980, 2016 and 2030.

para.p: Spatial simulation of annual minimum temperatures is useful for estimating joint return levels over certain regions. Fig. 7 shows three simulations of annual minima fields from M3, which show how the long-range dependence in the Brown–Resnick model results in annual minima that are either low or high throughout the region. The spatial heterogeneity is mostly due to non-stationarity in the marginal distributions.

figure.caption: Fig. 7Three simulated minimum temperature fields (∘C) for 2016.

para.p: Although the Stephenson–Tawn approach was found to perform well on simulated data (see the Supporting Information) when the true partition of the Brown–Resnick process is known, the results of our application show that it can be inappropriate in practice. The hierarchical model for the marginals does not even give a good fit of the marginal GEV distributions, notwithstanding the additional flexibility provided by the random effects.

We explain this by two factors: the use of the joint model for the minima and the partition, and the declustering. The first of these requires good agreement of the data with the distribution of the block maxima and the partition, and this is a strong assumption in practice. Although the Brown–Resnick dependence structure is quite flexible for modeling stationary isotropic dependence structures, the distribution of the underlying partition can be very different from the partition obtained through the declustering. In the univariate case, previous studies have shown that declustering can bias estimators of the marginal parameters if the clusters are poorly-defined, and we can expect similar problems in the multivariate case. In our application, assuming that data separated by more than five days are independent in pairs results in small numbers of clusters for each year, see Fig. 8, corresponding to strong dependence. A similar number of clusters for a Brown–Resnick process can only be obtained if the dependence in the process is very strong, and this is incompatible with the empirical extremal coefficients shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 8 also shows the sizes of the partitions used in the MCMC algorithm for the partition-free model; in several cases the size of the partition from the declustering procedure corresponds to low probability for the partition-free model. To further compare the partitions from the MCMC algorithm with the partition from the declustering procedure, we computed the Rand index (31), which is, for each year, the proportion of pairs of locations that are simultaneously either together or separate in both partitions; we then averaged the Rand index over the years. The Rand index varies from 0.52 to 0.63. The number of clusters is typically larger when imputed in the MCMC algorithm, and the relation with the occurrence dates is unclear. For example, in the winter 1973–1974, the annual minima at the 16 stations with no missing data occurred on four consecutive days and the declustering procedure finds one cluster, whereas just 7% of the partitions visited in the MCMC run have one cluster and 37% have four clusters or more.

figure.toccaption: 8Estimated distributions of the partition sizes for each year. Grey boxes shows the relative probability for each size (a wider box corresponds to a higher probability), estimated from the Gibbs sampler. The red points show the sizes of the partitions obtained using the declustering discussed in §4.2.3.
figure.caption: Fig. 8Estimated distributions of the partition sizes for each year. Grey boxes shows the relative probability for each size (a wider box corresponds to a higher probability), estimated from the Gibbs sampler. The red points show the sizes of the partitions obtained using the declustering discussed in §4.2.3.

para.p: For the model based on the declustering procedure, the best match of the Brown–Resnick process with the data and the partition is obtained with an inadequate fits of the marginal and dependence structures. We found that smaller values for σ and λ yield better visual diagnostics, with only a small decrease in the likelihood. Conditioning on a partition with few clusters forces the model to apply strong dependence and this compromises the fit of the marginal distributions.

These results suggest that a different declustering procedure must be used. We varied the number of days used in our declustering scheme, and also considered another scheme that forces the stations that are at least 150 km apart to be in different clusters. The parameter estimates changed with the scheme but the diagnostic plots were never very satisfactory.

We have shown how Bayesian inference can be conducted for the Brown–Resnick process, either using the occurrence times of maxima and a partition estimated by a declustering procedure, or by including the partition in an MCMC algorithm. The use of complex non-stationary hierarchical models helps to obtain good models for the marginal distributions of extremes over space, which cannot be obtained from trend surface models.

Simulations of extreme temperatures are useful to forecasting, but, additionally, conditional simulations of extreme temperatures would be useful to generate covariates that could be used as input for other models, as for example to link past outbreaks of Epirrita autumnata with extreme temperatures. Such conditional simulations could easily be obtained using methods of Dombry et al. (17).

Our application shows that using a fixed partition can strongly affect the estimation of the marginal and dependence parameters of a max-stable process. The partition adds powerful information into the model about the dependence structure, for which it acts as an informative prior. The use of a fixed partition reduces the uncertainty of the parameter estimates but can also bias the estimator. In a second approach we included the partition in the MCMC algorithm without using information on the occurrence times, and this seemed to work rather better. A more complex approach could use the occurrence times to construct a prior distribution on the space of the partitions, to add more information into the model and improve the efficiency of the estimation, while accounting for the uncertainty on the partition, but this seems likely to be rather complex. Wadsworth (46) proposed the use of second-order terms in the Stephenson–Tawn model to reduce potential bias due to the partition, but this seems difficult to use in our case because the number of terms to add to the likelihood would be huge and the MCMC algorithm would become even slower.

Our Bayesian model can be generalized in several ways. We focused on a stationary isotropic Brown–Resnick process for simplicity, and it appears to be sufficient for our application. A similar Bayesian hierarchical model can be constructed for the extremal-t process using ideas of Thibaud & Opitz (44), anisotropy would be easily incorporated using the idea of Engelke et al. (19), and so perhaps could the work of Huser & Genton (25) on non-stationary dependence models for extremes. However, the generalization of the present method to more complex models and larger datasets may be limited by computational feasibility. The Monte Carlo estimation of the likelihood is critical to keep the running times reasonable, and is relatively fast and accurate in low dimensions, but with more sites, more simulations may be needed to obtain reliable inference.

The model predicts an increase of 0.6∘C per decade in the mean annual minimum temperatures in northern Fennoscandia. Further work would be valuable to validate the predictions from our model and to quantify the possible effects of global change on forests. The linear trend is a simple model to provide sensible short-term predictions, but more complex approaches might be valuable, though limited by the availability of reliable data. One possibility would be to link the changes in extreme temperatures to mean temperatures and use predictions from global climate models under different scenarios as inputs to forecasting.

This work was undertaken while E.T. was at EPFL, Switzerland, with support from the Swiss National Science Foundation. E.T. and D.S.C.’s work at CSU was partially supported by US National Science Foundation Grant DMS-1243102. The temperature data is from the Finnish Meteorological Institute database for Finland, and from the European Climate Assessment & Dataset database (http://www.ecad.eu) for Sweden and Norway. This work was motivated by discussions with Seppo Neuvonen, who pointed out to us the relevance of winter minimum temperatures to insect outbreaks.

para.p: Temporal dependence complicates the estimation of extremal distributions. For the Stephenson–Tawn model, declustering must be used to identify independent events. We use a space-time declustering procedure based on the choice of a time-lag, after which we consider the data are independent. We investigated temporal dependence in daily minimum temperatures using the extremogram (50),

Math.text: varrho * list@(h, s _ j) = Pr * conditional-set@(Y * open-interval@(s _ j, t + h) > u, Y * open-interval@(s _ j, t) > u)

para.p: computed from the daily data ⁢Y(sj,t) at location sj and time t, for a high threshold u. The extremograms were computed using the %95 empirical quantiles for each series as thresholds and, because of possible non-stationarity, confidence bounds for testing independence were computed by random permutation of the data within each year: this broke the dependence while conserving the possibly different marginal distributions for each year. Fig. S1 shows that the dependence is strong for the first few days and vanishes after approximately five to ten days.

figure.toccaption: S1Extremogram with %95 confidence level for independence (red dashed line).
figure.caption: Fig. S1Extremogram with %95 confidence level for independence (red dashed line).

para.p: Max-stable processes provide a class of suitable models for extremes of asymptotically dependent processes. Other models may be preferred in case of asymptotic dependence. Serial dependence complicates the analysis of spatial dependence, as values occurring on consecutive days are likely to correspond to the same event. Hence extremal measures to check for asymptotic dependence, for example those suggested by Coles et al. (49), cannot be based on the daily data solely; their computation would require a complicated pre-processing of the data. We looked at plots for pairs of annual minima and for indices of weaker dependence in the lower tails. Fig. S2 shows the dependence between the annual minima at three pairs of distant stations. These plots seems to indicate the data are dependent over the entire range of distances.

figure.toccaption: S2Pairs plots for the winter temperature minima (∘C) at stations 3, 13 and 18.
figure.caption: Fig. S2Pairs plots for the winter temperature minima (∘C) at stations 3, 13 and 18.

appendix.title: Appendix S.3Prior distributions used in the Bayesian hierarchical model
appendix.toctitle: S.3Prior distributions used in the Bayesian hierarchical model

para.p: The choices of prior distributions and hyper parameters are given in Table 2. The hyper parameters were chosen to yield vague priors for all parameters except those of the latent Gaussian field. The prior distributions for β and τ2 were chosen to obtain conjugate full conditional distributions for these parameters, respectively normal and inverse-Gamma, see Davison et al. (51). For the other parameters, no conjugate priors seems to exist: their values were updated using a Metropolis–Hastings algorithm.

table.toccaption: 2Prior distributions and hyper parameters used in the hierarchical model.
table.caption: Table 2Prior distributions and hyper parameters used in the hierarchical model.

appendix.title: Appendix S.4Simulation study for the Bayesian model with the partition known
appendix.toctitle: S.4Simulation study for the Bayesian model with the partition known

para.p: We investigated the ability the MCMC algorithm to provide accurate estimation of model parameters using simulation. This especially important because of the use of an estimator for the likelihood in the MCMC algorithm, which is non-standard and can bias the estimation. We simulated 50 datasets from a non-stationary Brown–Resnick process and recorded the true generating partition; we used the algorithm of Dieker & Mikosch (52) to avoid any bias due to approximate simulation. We chose the parameters of our simulation to agree with our original dataset: we used the same locations, the same number of years, deleted the missing data, and set the parameters of the marginal and dependence parameters to the estimated values from the partition-free Bayesian model (Table 2). For each of the 50 simulations we ran 30 independent MCMC algorithms of length 3500. The first 1000 iterations of each Markov chain were discarded as burn-in period. We then merged the chains and calculated their mean and quantiles.

Fig. S3 shows the difference between the mean of the posterior distributions and the true values, and Fig. S4 shows the empirical coverages of credible intervals. Despite the short Markov chains, the results suggest that the MCMC algorithm provides sensible inferences for the model parameters: the posterior means are close to the true values and the empirical coverages of the credible intervals are close to the nominal values.

figure.toccaption: S3Boxplots of differences between the true values and the posterior means from the MCMC algorithm. Boxplots shows the values for 50 simulations. For the location parameters, the differences for all ⁢μ(sj,0), =j1,…,D, are shown in the boxplot.
figure.caption: Fig. S3Boxplots of differences between the true values and the posterior means from the MCMC algorithm. Boxplots shows the values for 50 simulations. For the location parameters, the differences for all ⁢μ(sj,0), =j1,…,D, are shown in the boxplot.

figure.toccaption: S4Empirical coverage (black dashed lines) of the credible intervals obtained the MCMC algorithm for 50 simulations of Brown–Resnick processes. The grey dashed lines show the %95 confidence bands for 50 replicates. The diagonal solid line indicates perfect performance.
figure.caption: Fig. S4Empirical coverage (black dashed lines) of the credible intervals obtained the MCMC algorithm for 50 simulations of Brown–Resnick processes. The grey dashed lines show the %95 confidence bands for 50 replicates. The diagonal solid line indicates perfect performance.

appendix.title: Appendix S.5Diagnostics for the MCMC sample for the partition-free Bayesian model
appendix.toctitle: S.5Diagnostics for the MCMC sample for the partition-free Bayesian model

para.p: Fig. S5 shows diagnostics for the MCMC algorithm. For ease of presentation the Markov chains were thinned to every 50 values. The autocorrelation is quite strong for the location parameters because of the use of a joint proposal for the 20 sites, but is weaker for the other parameters.

figure.toccaption: S5Diagnostics for the MCMC samples: trace plot, autocorrelation function and histogram. On the histograms, the dotted line shows the density of the prior distribution (if any), the red dot is the mean of the Markov chain and the red segment shows the %95 credible interval.
figure.caption: Fig. S5Diagnostics for the MCMC samples: trace plot, autocorrelation function and histogram. On the histograms, the dotted line shows the density of the prior distribution (if any), the red dot is the mean of the Markov chain and the red segment shows the %95 credible interval.

appendix.title: Appendix S.6Further diagnostics for model checking

para.p: We assessed the fit of the three models (the trend surface model, the Bayesian model with declustering, and the partition free Bayesian model) through marginal QQ-plots, pairwise extremal coefficients, and QQ-plots for multivariate quantities over some groups of stations.

Figs. S6–S8 show the marginal QQ-plots. Several points are outside the confidence bands for the trend surface and the Stephenson–Tawn models. The QQ-plots are satisfactory for the partition-free Bayesian model.

Figs. S9 and S10 show the QQ-plots for the minimum and average of winter minimum temperatures over four groups of stations. The trend surface and Stephenson–Tawn models do not perform very well. The fit is satisfactory for the partition-free Bayesian model, with all points inside the 95% confidence bands.

figure.toccaption: S6Marginal QQ-plots for the fitted GEV distributions from the trend surface model. Quantiles are given on the unit Fréchet scale.
figure.caption: Fig. S6Marginal QQ-plots for the fitted GEV distributions from the trend surface model. Quantiles are given on the unit Fréchet scale.

figure.caption: Fig. S7Marginal QQ-plots for the fitted GEV distributions from the Bayesian model based on the declustering. Quantiles are given on the unit Fréchet scale.

figure.toccaption: S8Marginal QQ-plots for the fitted GEV distributions from the partition-free Bayesian model. Quantiles are given on the unit Fréchet scale.
figure.caption: Fig. S8Marginal QQ-plots for the fitted GEV distributions from the partition-free Bayesian model. Quantiles are given on the unit Fréchet scale.

Grey dashed lines are %95 confidence bands.
